summary.long: Song Of Solomon is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth: for thy love is better than wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of the savor of thy good ointments, thy name is as an ointment poured out: therefore the virgins love thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Draw me: we will run after thee: the King hath brought me into his chambers: we will rejoice and be glad in thee: we will remember thy love more than wine: the righteous do love thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am black, O daughters of Jerusalem, but comely, as the tents of Kedar, and as the curtains of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Regard ye me not because I am black: for the sun hath looked upon me. The sons of my mother were angry against me: they made me the keeper of the vines: but I kept not mine own vine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Show me, O thou whom my soul loveth, where thou feedest, where thou liest at noon: for why should I be as she that turneth aside to the stocks of thy companions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If thou know not, O thou the fairest among women, get thee forth by the steps of the flock, and feed thy kids by the tents of the shepherds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have compared thee, O my love, to the troupe of horses in the chariots of Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy cheeks are comely with rows of stones, and thy neck with chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will make thee borders of gold with floods of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the King was at his repast, my spikenard gave the smell thereof.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved is as a bundle of myrrh unto me: he shall lie between my breasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved is as a cluster of camphire unto me in the vines of En Gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My love, behold, thou art fair: behold, thou art fair: thine eyes are like the doves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved, behold, thou art fair, and pleasant: also our bed is green.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The beams of our house are cedars, our rafters are of fir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the rose of the field, and the lily of the valleys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Like a lily among the thorns, so is my love among the daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Like the apple tree among the trees of the forest, so is my well-beloved among the sons of men: under his shadow had I delight, and sat down: and his fruit was sweet unto my mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought me into the wine cellar, and love was his banner over me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay me with flagons, and comfort me with apples: for I am sick of love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His left hand is under mine head, and his right hand doth embrace me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor waken my love, until she please.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is the voice of my well-beloved: behold, he cometh leaping by the mountains, and skipping by the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved is like a roe, or a young hart: lo, he standeth behind our wall, looking forth of the windows, showing himself through the grates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved spake and said unto me, Arise, my love, my fair one, and come thy way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For behold, winter is past: the rain is changed, and is gone away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The flowers appear in the earth: the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fig tree hath brought forth her young figs: and the vines with their small grapes have cast a savor: arise my love, my fair one, and come away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My dove, that art in the holes of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs, show me thy sight, let me hear thy voice: for thy voice is sweet, and thy sight comely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take us the foxes, the little foxes, which destroy the vines: for our vines have small grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved is mine, and I am his: he feedeth among the lilies,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Until the daybreak, and the shadows flee away: return, my well-beloved, and be like a roe, or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In my bed by night I sought him that my soul loved: I sought him, but I found him not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will rise therefore now, and go about in the city, by the streets, and by the open places, and will seek him that my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found him not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The watchmen that went about the city, found me: to whom I said, Have you seen him whom my soul loveth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I had passed a little from them, then I found him whom my soul loved: I took hold on him, and left him not, till I had brought him unto my mother’s house, into the chamber of her that conceived me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor waken my love until she please.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is she that cometh up out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke perfumed with myrrh and incense, and with all the spices of the merchant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold his bed, which is Solomon’s: threescore strong men are round about it, of the valiant men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They all handle the sword, and are expert in war, everyone hath his sword upon his thigh for the fear by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made himself a palace of the trees of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the pillars thereof of silver, and the pavement thereof of gold, the hangings thereof of purple, whose midst was paved with the love of the daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come forth, ye daughters of Zion, and behold the King Solomon with the crown, wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his marriage, and in the day of the gladness of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, thou art fair, my love: behold, thou art fair: thine eyes are like the doves: among thy locks thine hair is like the flock of goats, which look down from the mountain of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep in good order, which go up from the washing: which every one brings out twins, and none is barren among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet, and thy talk is comely: thy temples are within thy locks as a piece of a pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy neck is as the tower of David built for defense: a thousand shields hang therein, and all the targets of the strong men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy two breasts are as two young roes that are twins, feeding among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Until the day break, and the shadows fly away, I will go into the mountain of myrrh, and to the mountain of incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thou art all fair my love, and there is no spot in thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse, even with me from Lebanon, and look from the top of Amana, from the top of Senir, and Hermon, from the dens of the lions, and from the mountains of the leopards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My sister, my spouse, thou hast wounded mine heart: thou hast wounded mine heart with one of thine eyes, and with a chain of thy neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My sister, my Spouse, how fair is thy love? how much better is thy love than wine? and the savor of thine ointments than all spices?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy lips, my Spouse, drop as honeycombs: honey and milk are under thy tongue, and the savor of thy garment is as the savor of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My sister, my spouse is as a garden enclosed, as a spring shut up, and a fountain sealed up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy plants are as an orchard of pomegranates with sweet fruits, as camphire, spikenard,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even spikenard, and saffron: calamus, and cinnamon, with all the trees of incense, myrrh and aloes, with all the chief spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O fountain of the gardens, O well of living waters, and the springs of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Arise, O North, and come, O South, and blow on my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out: let my well-beloved come to his garden, and eat his pleasant fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am come into my garden, my sister, my spouse, I gathered my myrrh with my spice: I ate mine honeycomb with mine honey, I drank my wine with my milk: eat, O friends, drink, and make you merry, O well-beloved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I sleep, but mine heart waketh, it is the voice of my well-beloved that knocketh, saying, Open unto me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled: for mine head is full of dew, and my locks with the drops of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have put off my coat, how shall I defile [put] it on? I have washed my feet, how shall I defile them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door, and mine heart was affectioned toward him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I rose up to open to my well-beloved, and mine hands did drop down myrrh, and my fingers pure myrrh upon the handles of the bar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I opened to my well-beloved: but my well-beloved was gone and past: mine heart was gone when he did speak: I sought him, but I could not find him: I called him, but he answered me not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The watchmen that were about the city, found me: they smote me, and wounded me: the watchmen of the walls took away my veil from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if you find my well-beloved, that you tell him that I am sick of love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O the fairest among women, what is thy well-beloved more than other well-beloved? what is thy well-beloved more than another lover, that thou dost so charge us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved is white and ruddy, the chiefest of ten thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His head is as fine gold, his locks curled, and black as a raven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His eyes are like doves upon the rivers of waters, which are washed with milk, and remain by the full vessels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His cheeks are as a bed of spices, and as sweet flowers, and his lips like lilies dropping down pure myrrh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His hands as rings of gold set with the chrysolite, his belly like white ivory covered with sapphires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His legs are as pillars of marble set upon sockets of fine gold: his countenance as Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His mouth is as sweet things, and he is wholly delectable: this is my well-beloved, and this is my lover, O daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O the fairest among women, whither is thy well-beloved gone? whither is thy well-beloved turned aside, that we may seek him with thee?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My well-beloved is gone down into his garden to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am my well-beloved’s, and my well-beloved is mine, who feedeth among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thou art beautiful, my love, as Tirzah, comely as Jerusalem, terrible as an army with banners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Turn away thine eyes from me: for they overcome me: thine hair is like a flock of goats, which look down from Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep, which go up from the washing, which every one bring out twins, and none is barren among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy temples are within thy locks as a piece of a pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are threescore Queens, and fourscore concubines, and of the damsels without number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But my dove is alone, and my undefiled, she is the only daughter of her mother, and she is dear to her that bare her: the daughters have seen her, and counted her blessed: even the Queens and the concubines, and they have praised her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is she that looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon, pure as the sun, terrible as an army with banners!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I went down to the garden of nuts, to see the fruits of the valley, to see if the vine budded, and if the pomegranates flourished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I knew nothing, my soul set me as the chariots of my noble people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Return, return, O Shulamite, return: return that we may behold thee. What shall you see in the Shulamite, but as the company of an army?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How beautiful are thy goings with shoes, O prince’s daughter! the joints of thy thighs are like jewels: the work of the hand of a cunning workman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy navel is as a round cup that wanteth not liquor: thy belly is as an heap of wheat compassed about with lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy two breasts are as two young roes that are twins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy neck is like a tower of ivory; thine eyes are like the fish pools in Heshbon by the gate of Bath Rabbim: thy nose is as the tower of Lebanon that looketh toward Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thine head upon thee is as scarlet, and the bush of thine head like purple: the king is tied in the rafters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How fair art thou, and how pleasant art thou, O my love, in pleasures!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This thy stature is like a palm tree, and thy breasts like clusters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said, I will go up into the palm tree, I will take hold of her boughs: thy breasts shall now be like the clusters of the vine: and the savor of thy nose like apples,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the roof of thy mouth like good wine, which goeth straight to my well-beloved, and causeth the lips of the ancient to speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am my well-beloved’s, and his desire is toward me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come my well-beloved, let us go forth into the field: let us remain in the villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let us get up early to the vines, let us see if the vine flourish, whither it hath budded the small grape, or whither the pomegranates flourish: there will I give thee my love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The mandrakes have given a smell, and in our gates are all sweet things, new and old: my well-beloved, I have kept them for thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Oh that thou werest as my brother that sucked the breasts of my mother: I would find thee without, I would kiss thee, then they should not despise thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will lead thee and bring thee into my mother’s house: there thou shalt teach me: and I will cause thee to drink spiced wine, and new wine of the pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His left hand shall be under mine head, and his right hand shall embrace me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that you stir not up, nor waken my love until she please.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Who is this that cometh up out of the wilderness, leaning upon her well-beloved?) I raised thee up under an apple tree: there the mother conceived thee: there she conceived that bare thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Set me as a seal on thine heart, and as a signet upon thine arm: for love is strong as death: jealousy is cruel as the grave: the coals thereof are fiery coals, and a vehement flame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Much water cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man should give all the substance of his house for love, they would greatly contemn it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have a little sister, and she hath no breasts: what shall we do for our sister when she shall be spoken for?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If she be a wall, we will build upon her a silver palace: and if she be a door, we will keep her in with boards of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am a wall, and my breasts are as towers: then was I in his eyes as one that findeth peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had a vine in Baal Hamon: he gave the vineyard unto keepers: everyone bringeth for the fruit thereof a thousand pieces of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But my vineyard which is mine, is before me: to thee, O Solomon, appertaineth a thousand pieces of silver, and two hundred to them that keep the fruit thereof.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O thou that dwellest in the gardens, the companions hearken unto thy voice: cause me to hear it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O my well-beloved, flee away and be like unto the roe, or to the young hart upon the mountains of spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator
